sections.content: Aquascaping content showcases living art—planted tanks, reef setups, and underwater landscapes. Filming through glass presents challenges: reflections, color accuracy, and capturing movement. Successful aquascaping YouTubers master these technical hurdles. Here's the gear that works.

faq.question: How to avoid glass reflections?
faq.answer: Dark room, matte black cloth around camera, lens hood pressed close to glass. Polarizing filter helps some situations. Film at slight angle if straight-on reflects. Test before full shoot.

faq.question: Best time to film aquarium?
faq.answer: When fish are active and plants pearling (producing oxygen bubbles). Avoid right after feeding—cloudy water. Morning light plus tank light can work. Consistent tank lighting preferred.

faq.question: Camera for aquarium filming?
faq.answer: Sony A6400 or similar with manual controls popular. Macro lens for detail shots. 4K for cropping flexibility. Manual white balance essential—auto WB fights tank lights constantly.

faq.question: How to capture accurate colors?
faq.answer: Custom white balance with white card in tank. Post-processing adjustment often needed. Different LED spectrums (planted vs reef) require different settings. Test and adjust per tank.
